name: INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT

values.comments:
The course undertakes a rigorous study of concepts and evidence relevant to investment management and is designed to acquaint the student with the concepts of portfolio analysis in the general area of institutional investment management. The course discusses principles for managing financial assets. These principles apply, for example, to managing corporate pension funds, bank-administered trusts, and other institutional funds. Topics include asset allocation, diversification, long-short strategies, factor models, long- horizon investing, portfolio optimization, hedge funds, mutual funds, behavioral finance, performance evaluation, trading, and simulation. The course does not deal with individual security valuation, i.e., “equity research” or “stock picking.” Students will learn how to establish appropriate investment objectives, develop optimal portfolio strategies, estimate risk-return tradeoffs, and evaluate investment performance. Many of the latest quantitative approaches are discussed. The prerequisites are Fin 601 and Stat 621 (MBA students) or Fin 100 and Stat 101 (undergraduates). Given that investment management requires one to analyze and deal effectively with uncertainty, a good grounding in statistics is essential, and familiarity with statistics should extend through multiple regression, covariance, and correlation. 

Students described this course as being “extremely useful”, and one student felt “this should be a required class at Wharton”. Students felt that it provided a “general background to approach quantitative investment strategies”. Most students called the course material “confusing” and felt that it moved at too fast of a pace, as it is “very math and statistics-based” and required mathematical proofs. Students commented that the fast pace of the lectures was “not very conducive to learning the material”, and others complained that the class was “too theoretical” and lacking practical examples that would have been appreciated. Students felt that the case studies on which the lectures focused were “irrelevant for many of the classes.”

Students described Professor Stambaugh as “very approachable” to those students requesting help and “friendly”. However, most students were not impressed with the lectures and felt that Professor Stambaugh did not communicate the subject matter very well and had trouble stimulating student interest. Students felt that Professor Stambaugh’s lectures were often confusing and did not connect to previous and subsequent lectures. Despite praising Professor Stambaugh as being “very knowledgeable,” most students did not find his lectures engaging. One student commented that to study for exams “most people ignored their class notes and just memorized answers from the sample questions.” 

Course grades are based on two exams (each 30%), four project write-ups (20% in total), and class participation (20%). Students complained that there was “no clear indication of how grades were distributed” for the projects. One student commented that he appreciated Professor Stambaugh’s use of the MBA curve “or mix [of] the MBA and undergrad curves” for grading.
